You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: The sound of the cell phone cut through the morning air like a warm knife through a stick of butter, the dulcet tones of Adele's Hello becoming a cannon blast in the silence of the apartment. The sudden impact of the sound catches her off guard, and she jerks ever so subtly, dousing her knuckles and the granite beneath with black coffee. Were it not for the fact that the coffee cup had been sitting undisturbed for 45 minutes, it would have certainly burned her hands when the liquid splashed over, but as so many things have before, it had gotten away from her. It was a Saturday, her one day out of the office, and while it was true that she wasn't expecting any calls, she should not have been so surprised, because of course, somebody always needed something. On any other day, this wouldn"t be troubling, but today, it is. In this instance, the sound of Adele in the late morning could only mean one thing; somebody had fucked up. Barely registering the coffee stains on her fingers, she taps accept and brings the phone to her ear.


"What is it Allison?" she asks with a frustration that is as palpable as it is cutting. Allison was her assistant, and she already knows what she was going to hear, but sometimes, you have to let people answer questions you know the answer to, so they feel the gravity on their own lips. There is a pause on the other end, the distinct silence of apprehension, before Allisons timid voice breaks through. "Hi ma'am, sorry to bother you on your day off, but…" she trails off, unsure of how to word the coming letdown in a way that would not be her own undoing. Her boss was an intense woman, and this intensity was about to bubble over. "Out with it Allison, I haven't got all day to wait for you to collect your thoughts," and as if her words weren't sharp enough, she adds "if you have any, that is." Allison's voice catches in her throat, and she changes course, no longer caring to present her bad news with any tact. "The deal with Maybelline has fallen through, they've decided to go with another firm." There it is, the terrible truth, and even though she knew what Allison was going to say, the sting is just as great. The fire that was already brewing within her grows ever more. She is having an awful morning, and now the biggest deal of the year has eluded her grasp; so much for Saturday. Reeling from anger and disappointment, she doesn't pay any mind to Allisons frantic mumbling, as she clutches the phone with an iron grip. She takes a deep breath, and interrupts the panicking assistant. "Allison, stop talking," She says rather coldly, "I will be in the office in 20 minutes, gather the partners, and for godsakes, have a pot of coffee ready." She hangs up before Allison has a chance to say anything further. For a moment all is quiet, as she collects her thoughts. She is used to being on call seven days a week; there is always a fire that needs to be put out, but she needed today. The idea of facing the world this morning feels terribly heavy.

As she surveys the sleek, minimalist design of her penthouse apartment, a surge of revulsion washes over her. The sterile aesthetic, once a symbol of sophistication, now feels suffocating. With each pristine surface and carefully curated piece of furniture, her anger simmers beneath the surface, threatening to boil over. Before she even knows what she"s done, the coffee cup smashes into a framed picture on the far wall, sending both crashing to the ground in a spray of broken glass and ceramic shards. She lets out a guttural scream, containing the fullness of her anger, and perhaps a bit of sadness. As it leaves her body, and reason seeps back into her mind, she sees what she has done and is overcome with another familiar feeling; grief. "No, no, no…" she desperately whispers to herself as she rushes to the wreckage on the far side of the room, and begins digging through the pile of glass with reckless abandon, cutting her hands in the process, but paying it no mind. How could she be so foolish, so stupid? In the shattered remains of the framed photograph, fragments of memories surface – a smile captured in a moment of joy, a shared laugh frozen in time. At last, her bleeding hands come upon a now crumpled photograph, and she does her best to smooth it out on the edge of her coffee table. "I'm sorry, I'm so sorry," she sobs to only herself, as nobody else is there to hear it. The white border of the photograph has taken on a pink hue from her bleeding hands, and the table edge catches a small rip in the paper, and the photograph tears in two. A look of horror spreads across her face, and she collapses to the ground in a pool of tears. As she cradles the torn photograph in her trembling hands, she is overcome by a wave of regret and sorrow. The image, once a cherished memory, now lies in tatters. In the silence of the empty apartment, her whispered apologies are met with only the echo of her own despair.

When she collects herself, she gets a hand broom and a dustpan from the kitchen closet and sweeps up the glass without a word. She dumps the shards and the remains of the photograph haphazardly into the trash can beneath the sink, nearly spilling the mess right back onto the tile. She is not thinking now, but going through the motions; there isn't time to feel sorry for herself, for there is business to be done, and sinking ships to salvage. She rinses her hand in the bathroom sink and winces at the sting of the cold water hitting her wounds; it's okay, she thinks, I had it coming. When the cuts are thoroughly cleaned and free of glass, she tightly wraps them with bandages from the medicine cabinet, and dons a pair of Versace leather gloves. No sense in having to answer any unwanted questions at the office. Once she has put herself back together, she takes a deep breath, and steps out of her apartment and into the elevator. She rides down 74 floors without a word, greeting nobody that enters the small space. When she lands in the lobby, she ignores the doorman's pleasant goodbyes and steps into the cool spring air of West 61st Street. Her office is only a few blocks from her penthouse, so she feels no need to have the valet bring her car around, and resigns herself to the walk; the car will continue to gather dust in the garage. When she arrives at the agency, there will no doubt be a boardroom of sweaty yesmen waiting for her to save the day, so she will use this time to come up with a strategy. Advertising can be a cutthroat world, and she didn't become one of the best by accepting no as an answer. The Maybeline deal will be no different; somehow, she will bring them back around, even if she has to sacrifice. She is no stranger to sacrifice.

On the bustling streets of New York, one can expect to see any number of interesting characters: homeless men begging for change, a man with a box of CDs extorting people for five dollar bills, end-of-the-world prophets, and sometimes, very public arguments that are best left to the bedroom. On her daily walk to work, she has become an expert in tuning out the wider world entirely, keeping a stony expression and walking with purpose. After the morning she has had, she sinks right back into this familiar demeanor, paying no mind to the controlled chaos of city life. She walks past newspaper stands, and cardboard cutouts of superheroes, and doesn't break her steady stride when the newsboys try to catch her attention. She had set aside this particular Saturday months ago and wants to finish this business with haste so she may return to solitude in her lonely high-rise apartment. She is one block away from her office when she is stopped by traffic at the crosswalk, waiting alongside a crowd of various people for the light to turn green so she can simply get on with it. As she waits, a man approaches to her right, shepherding a little girl with golden blonde hair who could be no older than six. Atop her head is a plastic tiara that reads in big, obnoxious cursive letters "Birthday Princess." The father is carrying a set of mylar balloons that could be any number of Disney princesses, but she is unsure; she hasn't kept track of princesses for some time. The father grabs his daughter's hand and pulls her closer, "Keep near me Ava, we don't want any cars to get you on your birthday." Ava furrows her brow in a look that could say "who would dare run over a princess," but she relents and hugs her dad's leg. "Is this close enough daddy," she says with a mischievous smile, "nobody can get me now!" The stoplight feels as though it is lasting an eternity, and the woman begins tapping her foot restlessly. The father is looking at his daughter with an exaggerated look of exasperation that could say "I can't take you anywhere!" and Ava bursts into a fit of giggles. The light turns green and the father scoops up Ava in his arms and says "Alright princess Ava, let's get you to your birthday party," and Ava cheers as they begin to step across the crosswalk. As she observes the interaction between the father and daughter, a voice whispers in the depths of her mind, questioning the choices that have led her to this moment. Doubt creeps in, like tendrils of smoke curling around her thoughts. She pushes these fleeting thoughts aside, but they linger at the edges of her consciousness, stirring something within her. The scene before her stirs a quiet yearning, a whisper of something lost. Memories, long buried, surface like ripples on a calm pond, hinting at what once was. She feels a pang in her chest, a fleeting sense of emptiness, as if something precious has slipped through her fingers. Yet, she brushes these feelings aside with practiced ease, burying them beneath layers of false resolve. The woman lets out a heavy sigh of relief and takes a step forward when something inside her stomach turns sour, and immense pressure falls upon her shoulders. All at once, her feet give out from under her, and she collapses to the sidewalk.

She lies flat on her back on the pavement, her arms and legs spread out in the vague shape of a snow angel, as a crowd of people gathers around her. They barrage her with a slew of concerns and questions: "What happened? Are you okay? Do you need help?" Outstretched hands appear all around her, and she opens her mouth to say she is fine and to leave her be when horror washes over her like a tidal wave. In a frantic and terrified voice, she screams, "I can't move my arms! I can't move my fucking arms!" Panic begins to consume her from the inside as she realizes she cannot move her legs either. She attempts to wiggle her fingers and toes, expecting them to remain frozen, but they do, in fact, wiggle to and fro. She comes to the conclusion that she isn't paralyzed, but she is unable to get up. It feels as though something or someone is holding her down, pinning her to the pavement. The crowd moves in closer as a million thoughts flow in and out of her whirling mind. She can move her head from side to side, but she cannot raise it. "Help me please, somebody help me up, I can't move!" she blurts out through desperate sobs, hoping either a good Samaritan or God will save her from this hellish moment. A large man with a bald head parts the murmuring crowd and approaches her, kneeling behind her head. "Don't worry, ma'am, I'm going to get you to a hospital," he says with a confidence that implies he was ready for this exact circumstance. He begins to slide his hands under her shoulders and pauses; a puzzled look appears on his haggard face. He moves to her legs and attempts the same maneuver and again finds no purchase. He steps back, visibly deflated, and rubs his smooth head. "I can't… I can't get my hands under you," he stammers, a little unsure of what he's saying. "It's like you're glued to the ground or something." She shoots him a look of bewildered disbelief and practically screeches, "What the fuck are you talking about?! Help me up, please!" Another man pushes through the crowd, eager to do what the previous man could not, and says, "Alright, let's get her up." Both men take place on either side of the woman and prepare to lift her as though they were about to move a dresser. They clutch the fabric of her jacket and pants and pull with all their might, when the fabric tears and both men tumble backward.

The crowd, now quite sizable, has begun to murmur amongst themselves, in awe of the curious spectacle. The woman has begun weeping openly, pleading for help in broken English interrupted by shuddered breath. One by one, people emerge from the crowd and attempt to lift her, and one by one, they all fail to move her even a single inch. Tears stream down her cheeks as she begs for help, her voice choked with fear and desperation. Each failed attempt to lift her only deepens her sense of helplessness, like a weight pressing down on her chest, suffocating her with dread. Arguments form in small groups about what the best course of action is, and somebody has the bright idea to call the police. After some time, the crowd disperses a bit as police officers and EMTs break through the spectacle and set up a perimeter. They too, attempt to pick up the woman, a stretcher waiting patiently nearby for her arrival, but it will remain empty. The emergency workers are no more able to lift her than the good Samaritans who tried before. All the while, the woman pleads and cries for help, a million horrible thoughts bombarding her brain. She watches as the police officers form a circle and discuss what exactly is happening here. One of the officers scratches his head, puzzled. "I"ve never seen anything like this," he mutters to his colleague. "You think it"s some kind of industrial adhesive?" They resolve to cut off her clothes to free her. Out come the knives and scissors, and they surround her once more. As the paramedics cut away her clothes, she shivers in the cold air, feeling exposed and vulnerable. The once-pristine fabric of her designer jacket and luxury pants lay in tatters around her, a stark contrast to her pale skin. Lying cold and mostly nude, as a crowd looks upon her pale body, she weeps in embarrassment as the EMTs once again gather around her to lift her up, and once again, fail. They quickly discover that they are not able to pull her now ruined clothes out from under her. There is a ruckus in the audience, as news vans and reporters arrive at the scene, eager to get the scoop on this bizarre story unfolding before them. The police officers remove them from the scene rather forcibly and set up sawhorses around the perimeter, but the reporters continue to crowd around the barrier, screaming out inappropriate questions and queries. "Ma'am, ma'am, are these police officers treating you okay?" yells a reporter with a bad toupee, "Ma'am, is this some kind of political statement?" yells another with makeup so thick, you could slice it like cake. Amidst the chaos, she feels herself slipping further into shock, her thoughts a jumbled mess of disbelief and confusion. Is this really happening to her? Is it some kind of nightmare she can"t wake up from? After a while, the police radio in for the firefighters.

As the blaring sirens of the fire trucks cut through the noise of the scene, a palpable sense of urgency grips the air. Onlookers exchange anxious glances, their murmurs growing louder with each passing moment, as the arrival of the firefighters promises a glimmer of hope amidst the chaos. They enter the space with a rather large and frightening electric saw. The woman lies there speechless as they saw through the concrete, showering her in a spray of sparks that lightly singe her flesh. They cut a perfect square around her body and approach with crowbars, anchoring them beneath the isolated concrete. Ten firemen attempt to pry the piece of sidewalk up with all their might, but it doesn't move an inch. Hours go by and day creeps into night, as the rescue workers try everything they can think of: forklifts, jackhammers, even a bucket loader. Nothing works, and the woman remains pinned to the earth. She stares out of glassy eyes as the simple plans of mice and men fail again and again to free her. With each futile attempt to dislodge her from her concrete prison, the woman"s despair deepens, mirrored in the weary faces of the firefighters. Exhausted and demoralized, they exchange worried glances that speak of their growing doubt. Her phone begins ringing constantly after a while, the sounds of Adele punctuating her nightmare, but nobody ever answers it. In the grand scheme of things, a cell phone seems like small potatoes. Amidst the backdrop of flashing lights, bystanders stand transfixed, their expressions ranging from shock to curiosity. Some exchange hushed whispers, speculating on the possibilities at play, and some whisper prayers under their breath, while others simply watch in morbid fascination. The woman feels every eye upon her. As the night bleeds into the morning, the crowd begins to thin as the police and EMTs simply give up. For some unknown reason, this woman cannot be moved, as though God were holding her down with his finger. A kind officer covers her with a blanket and feeds her by hand as she stares up at the tops of skyscrapers and the vacant blue sky. Something inside her has broken, and she no longer weeps. If there were a word she could say to release her from her prison on the sidewalk, it doesn't come.

Days go by slowly at first, and then quickly become weeks. Each passing day brings with it a growing numbness, a resignation to her fate that settles like a heavy blanket over her weary soul. At first, it seems as though the media storm will never let the spectacle end, as endless news teams and reporters descend upon the woman in the early days of her confinement. They batter her with questions and theories that range from the incredibly obvious to the downright absurd, but she pays them no mind, nor does she speak a word. The police keep the area cordoned off and stay with her for the first month, feeding her regularly and changing out her blankets. They do their best to keep her comfortable, but comfort feels like such an impossible thing to grant. All the while, she does nothing and says nothing. It seems as though her natural processes have shut down; even her breath becomes weak and shallow, and yet she lives. The reporters fall away, the crowds thin ever more, and her police guards go home, returning ever so often to feed her and provide her with sources of warmth on the colder days. After the first six months, she is largely left alone. Occasional outbursts of protest erupt among activists, their voices rising in defiance against the city"s neglect of the woman trapped in their midst. To quell them, the city votes on a measure to build an enclosure for the woman, and it narrowly passes on a vote of 26 - 25. This enclosure turns out to be little more than a canopy and a space heater. The larger world moves on, and people commute to work, stepping around the immovable woman as though she were rubbish on the sidewalk. Advertisement campaigns begin in the city at some point, attempting to draw tourism. Billboards pop up that declare in big bold letters, "Come see the immovable woman! The greatest mystery of mankind!" It is a big success at first, but after a few years, even the tourists stop visiting. Throughout this time, scientists from across the globe convene in symposiums and conferences, debating the intricacies of her condition and proposing wild theories to explain her inexplicable plight. They arrive in droves, bringing various indescribable instruments and attempting to discover the cause of the woman"s imprisonment. After endless theses and countless studies, the best they can do is give it a name: Sudden Intense Gravity Syndrome, or SIGS for short. It becomes the subject of infinite conspiracy theories for many years to come. When five years go by, even the curiosity of intellectuals runs out, as all of mankind eventually grows bored with its playthings.

The woman lies silently for many days and nights. Seasons pass like clockwork, and the city continues to change and evolve while she remains still. During the harsh winter months, the city offers her additional provisions to endure the biting cold, but as time passes, interest in helping her wanes completely. She becomes akin to the numerous statues and art installations that adorn New York City; a permanent fixture, unmoving and unchanging, seamlessly melding into the broader urban landscape. The buildings don't feel her endless cold stare, and the streets don't hear her soft cries in the night, but they stand in frozen solitude alongside her. In her immobility, she retreats deeper into the recesses of her mind, seeking respite in the vast expanse of her thoughts. She spends the first few years grappling with existential questions; pondering what, why, and how her situation came to be. She gets no closer to answers than any of the scientists who studied her previously, and learns to stop asking those questions. As curious as her predicament is, even the novelty of thinking about it becomes mundane after years, so she takes to other activities to occupy her mind. She counts the windows on all the buildings she can see, and memorizes the specific birds that fly by and occasionally land on her. She observes countless cars and listens to the myriad stories of passersby, gaining an almost intimate familiarity with those whose daily routines intersect with her path most frequently. Sometimes, she ventures into her memories, often triggering moments of sadness, the soft sound of her weeping drifting down the street as tears dampen the pavement beneath her. She does not mourn for the life that has been taken away from her, for she is convinced she never deserved it.
After ten years, she is completely resigned to her fate and awaits death. She wonders if anyone would even notice if she were gone. Would they simply step over her body, oblivious to her presence? And if they did notice, would they be able to remove her, or would she remain here, a permanent fixture in the city"s landscape? Will she have a funeral, and be buried with her loved ones, or will they simply melt her away until there's nothing left? She decides that it doesn't really matter, and welcomes the day with open arms. Even if she were suddenly freed, what kind of life awaited her? Her company had likely collapsed without her leadership, her penthouse seized by creditors. She has no one waiting for her, no home to return to. What kind of existence could she carve out for herself after this? What would her quality of life be like? Her body has been overtaken by moss and fungus, her hair a matted mess that no brush could penetrate. Her skin has hardened and taken the texture of a pumice stone. Her teeth feel like jagged rocks in her mouth, beyond saving after years of neglecting them. She imagines the absurdity of a dentist attempting a root canal on a prone patient lying on the sidewalk, the thought eliciting a weary smile on her cracked lips. What a show that would be! After all, there have been greater miracles. There have also been greater nightmares. To her best knowledge, she has never been sick, and nobody has run her over. While the city fed her pretty regularly in the beginning, they stopped doing that a few years ago, and yet she never hungers or thirsts. The horrifying thought begins to gnaw at her: What if she was immortal? The idea fills her with a desperate panic. 'Can I die?" she wonders anxiously. "Please, God, let me die." The prospect of endless existence weighed heavy on her soul, a burden she couldn"t bear. She thinks, 'There are people waiting for me, I can't be here forever!' Memories of past pain and trauma flood her mind, mingling with her current despair. She pushes them away, unwilling to confront the demons that lurk in her past. There are things she cannot bear to think about, wounds too deep to reopen. There are worse things in life than the view from the sidewalk."

2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.
3. Ensure the continuation is long enough to cover the necessary developments and messages.
response:
As the sun rose and set over the city, life moved at its relentless pace, indifferent to the woman’s plight. The seasons shifted, bringing with them the vibrancy of spring, the sweltering heat of summer, the brilliant colors of autumn, and the biting chill of winter. Yet, through it all, she remained, an immovable presence stitched into the fabric of New York, like an eternal monument to the forgotten.

After ten years anchored to that spot, her existence had become an enigma—a puzzle no one could solve. News of the "Immovable Woman" had faded into the shadows of urban legend, and while she was still a curiosity, the novelty had long since worn off. Children who once marveled at her with wide-eyed wonder became teenagers who shrugged her off as a mere quirk of the city. The activists who had once rallied around her story for social justice realized they had battles of their own to fight, and slowly, they too disappeared from her life.

But amid the silence, a lonely echo of hope still flickered within her, like the last embers of a fire refusing to die. It was a tangible yearning for connection, the hope that someone might notice her, see her for who she truly was, and perhaps even try to help her. She often thought about what she would say if someone ever asked her why she was there. "I wanted to be free," she would whisper, her voice carrying the weight of a thousand dreams. She longed to tell her story, to scream from her concrete prison that she was more than just a spectacle.

One day, while observing the city moving around her, she caught sight of a familiar figure in the periphery—an elderly woman, leaning heavily on a cane, wearing a faded trench coat that had seen better days. It was Mrs. Hollis, her former neighbor from years ago. The woman would often bring her cookies and engage her in pleasant conversation, despite their age difference. As Mrs. Hollis approached, she squinted, trying to make sense of the scene before her. The old woman paused, her eyes widening as she recognized the immovable figure on the sidewalk. 

“Ava?” Mrs. Hollis called out, her voice trembling with disbelief. The woman’s heart skipped; she hadn’t heard her name in so long. The sound was like a long-lost melody returning to her ears, resonating within her very core. “Ava, my dear!” the elderly woman continued, stepping closer, her face etched with concern and recognition. “What happened to you?”

The crowd that had formed around Ava murmured and stepped aside, drawn by the sudden shift in the atmosphere. For the first time in years, the immovable woman felt the stirrings of warmth in her heart as she realized someone still remembered her. “I… I don’t know,” she managed to whisper, feeling the years of despair surge forth like a tide. “I can’t move.”

Mrs. Hollis knelt beside her, gripping her cane tightly. “We’ll get you help,” she replied firmly, pulling out her cell phone. “Just hold on, dear.”

In that moment, something shifted deep within Ava. The embers of hope that had been flickering low suddenly blazed back to life. She remembered the warmth of genuine human connection, the feeling of being seen, and the possibility of change. The crowd watched with rapt attention as the elderly woman spoke to the operator, her voice filled with urgency. 

As the minutes turned into hours, an ambulance arrived, and paramedics rushed to the scene. They were astonished to find Ava still there, and her heart raced in anticipation as they examined her condition. The elderly woman remained at her side, holding her hand, whispering that everything would be alright. The paramedics, equipped with new technology, brought specialized equipment designed to assess her unusual situation.

“Okay, Ava, we’re going to try to lift you, but we need you to focus,” one of the paramedics instructed, his voice calm and steady. “We believe we can get you out of here, but we need you to help us as much as you can.”

Ava nodded slowly, a glimmer of determination igniting within her. For the first time in years, she felt a flicker of power returning to her body. She concentrated on her limbs, willing them to respond, clenching and unclenching her fingers. As the paramedics made their attempt, she felt warmth swell in her arms and legs, a sensation she had grown alien to.

She pressed her palms against the ground and imagined herself rising, pulling upon every ounce of willpower she had left. The paramedics lifted her, and to her astonishment, she felt the ground release its hold on her. With a sudden surge of energy, she sat up, gasping in disbelief as they supported her.

The crowd erupted into cheers, and as if propelled by a force greater than herself, she stood. Her legs trembled, and her body felt frail and weakened from years of immobility, but she was no longer held captive. The cheers rang in her ears, a melody of hope that drowned out the nightmares that had overshadowed her for so long.

“Take it slow, Ava,” Mrs. Hollis said, her eyes gleaming with tears of joy. “You’re free now, sweetheart.”

As the paramedics guided her toward the ambulance, Ava turned to face the crowd, her heart pounding with emotion. She had spent years feeling invisible, yet here were people rallying behind her, witnesses to her rebirth. The world had not forgotten her after all. 

In the ambulance, they wrapped her in warm blankets and checked her vitals, but all she could think about was what lay ahead. For the first time in a decade, she felt a sense of possibility unfurling within her—a chance to reclaim her life, to rewrite her story. 

As she looked out of the window, the city transformed before her eyes. The skyscrapers loomed high above, but they no longer felt like prison bars. Instead, they whispered of potential, each building a testament to resilience and rebirth. The air buzzed with energy, and she realized how much she had missed life, the chaos of it, the beauty woven into every moment.

Her thoughts danced, fluttering between excitement and trepidation, as she contemplated the future. What would she do now? How could she rebuild? The questions welled up within her, but they felt different this time, infused with a sense of agency she had not felt in years. 

Ava knew the road ahead wouldn’t be easy. She had spent a decade in a state of limbo, and the world had changed in ways she could hardly grasp. Friends had moved on, her career had vanished, and she would have to forge a new path. But as the ambulance sped through the streets, she felt the weight of despair dissipate, replaced by a burgeoning sense of purpose.

For the first time in a long time, Ava was ready to embrace whatever came next. She was alive, she was free, and she would face the world head-on, determined to reclaim her identity and her place within it. She had spent years as a monument of endurance, and now, she would strive to become a beacon of hope, a testament to the resilience of the human spirit.

As they arrived at the hospital, Ava took a deep breath, knowing this was just the beginning. The world awaited her return, and she was ready to write her own ending.

[Story]: The beach was a symbol of relaxation. It was where children played in the waves while the parents relaxed in the sun. Well, the parents let themselves bake in the sun until they realized they lost their kids. Then, they panicked and searched across the sands annoying everyone. Eventually, a helpful volleyball player showed up with the kids. You thank them until. Wait, why is your spouse staring so long at that volleyball player? Sure, they look like you did younger. Well, more like a young fit version of you. Okay, they looked nothing like you did, and why was your spouse standing so close. This was a disaster. We should"ve never came here on family vacation.


To most people who haven"t had such a dramatic experience, the beach was a nice place. It represented a freedom from modern stresses and a chance to enjoy the sun. Sandcastles lined the sands like an army defending its territory. Shells were collected as if they held monetary value. Such a shame this culture was destroyed by the Mierans.

Humans had always liked to take breaks, but the location was limited by time and resources. When the world was destroyed, the breaks turned into a night where two people guarded the door rather than three. The prime real estate became the pond a few blocks away to keep an eye on the supplies. Tourist traps became rusted as there was a lack of tourists to trap. Except for the dumbest people.

"Hurry up, we are going to be late," Polly yelled. Jim fell down the stairs. He had a beach towel on one arm and a tuxedo on his other.

"What is that for?" Polly grabbed the pants.

"You said bring a swimsuit," Jim said. Polly shook her head.

"Why I am surrounded by idiots." She turned back to the stairs. "Check-in ends at four pm."

"Isn"t it your friend who"s in charge?" Olivia walked down the stairs carrying a handbag full of vacation essentials. Her dress was loose and flowing.

"He told me that he wouldn"t make exceptions," Polly said.

"That makes sense. If you were my friend, I wouldn"t make exceptions for you too," Olivia replied. Polly ignored her which angered Olivia.

"Reid! Frida! Get down here," Polly yelled. Frida ran down the stairs. She was most excited about the possibility of hunting. As such, she had a crossbow, a harpoon, and a flare. Her prey wasn"t sharks; it was crabs. Reid followed her down in a swimsuit. With every step, he practiced flexing and posing. His body was adequate. His biceps were present, but they didn"t bulge. If he held his breath, his torso acquired some definition. In total, he was making a fool of himself.

"I"m ready to mingle." He shimmied at the bottom step. Polly and Olivia reacted with horror while Jim nodded his head.

"We"re going to be so popular." Jim put his arm around Reid who shook him off.

"Just me. You can be my wingman," Reid said.

"Sure thing," Jim replied.

"Whatever, let"s get going," Polly said. The five of them made their way out of their small house. The road to the vacation was long, and it took a few days travel by foot. They didn"t plan on travel time. Fortunately, Frida was skilled at capturing beasts (some of which were mutants) and tried all plants to ensure it wasn"t poisonous (Jim tried them as well because Frida was likely immune to all poisons). After their journey, they reached Pacifico City.

It was one of the few cities established after the war. The military ran the country, and Pacfico City wanted to cater to their needs. Multiple resorts sat close to the beach. By the resorts, there shooting ranges and ATVs for pleasure. There was an assortment of bars and restaurants as well. Each had its own signature dish or cocktail. There was one issue. The customers never came.

The upper brass couldn"t leave. The new military was disorganized, and vacations were an opportunity to be removed by force. The soldiers were forced to stay by their commanders. If they were going to be miserable, everyone else was going to be miserable as well. The result was a sad city filled with abandoned resorts. The weapons and ATVs were stolen by raiders who put it to better use. The bars and restaurants had their supplies looted, and the workers moved on.

The vacation house in question was a dingy hotel far from the beach. When the five arrived, a man sat behind the desk with his mouth open. A fly flew in and out of it. There was a wall with keys behind him. The man didn"t react when they entered. He did perk up when Polly hit the bell on his desk.

"Welcome to Tropical Fun. You missed check-in time," he said.

"Rick, it"s me. Can"t you make an exception," Polly replied.

"Check-in ends at four. It"s half past five." Rick pointed at the clock. Olivia looked down.

"That clock isn"t moving," she said. Rick looked down.

"Oh, I"ve only been working here for a few months. I inherited it from my uncle. He died in a mutant iguana attack," Rick said.

"Sorry for your loss," Polly said.

"Don"t be. I hated him." Rick turned around. He gave them two keys. Before arriving, it was agreed that Olivia would get a room by herself. Reid and Polly were okay with this because Jim and Frida slept on the floor. The floor was preferrable when they saw their rooms. Reid"s bed was simultaneously too hard and too soft, Polly"s was always wet, and Olivia"s had mutant bed bugs. The rooms smelled like burnt cabbage. The bathrooms were filled with flies and rodents.

"Well this is a disaster." Reid looked out the window. "There"s no one here to enjoy my show."

"Their loss." Olivia was hiding in the other room because she was scared of bugs. She wouldn"t let them know.

"No, every cloud has a silver lining." Reid turned with a smile on this face. "We are going to restore this city to its former glory.""

response:
**Continuation of the Story:**

Reid's enthusiasm was infectious, but it felt misplaced in that moment. The peeling paint, the smell of mildew mixed with decay, and the unsettling sounds of something scuttling under the floorboards were enough to give even the most optimistic soul pause. Still, it was clear Reid was undeterred by their surroundings.

"You really think we can help this place?" Polly raised an eyebrow. "We don’t even have a plan."

"Exactly!" Reid exclaimed, his eyes shining with a wild excitement. "We don’t need a plan. We need a mission! A calling! We can be the heroes that Pacifico City needs!"

"More like the fools it doesn’t," Olivia mumbled from behind the door where she was still hiding. She peeked out, clutching her handbag tightly, as if it were a lifebuoy in a storm.

Frida, ever the pragmatist, rolled her eyes but smiled slightly. "Reid, I admire your spirit, but we’re not equipped for this kind of rescue operation. We’ve got a crossbow and a flare—hardly the tools of urban recovery."

"But think about it! We can bring back tourism! We can make the resorts alive again! The military can’t keep this place under their thumb forever. We can host beach parties, crab hunts, races on the ATVs, and—"

"Okay, okay. I see where you’re going," Polly interrupted, trying to rein in Reid’s whirlwind of ideas. "But first, we need to figure out what we’re working with. If we’re going to help this city, we need to know what’s wrong."

The group reluctantly agreed to a plan. They decided to explore the hotel and the surrounding area for supplies and clues about the city’s decline. They had come to the Pacifico City for a vacation, but now it seemed they were destined to be its unlikely saviors.

As they traversed the decrepit halls of the hotel, they found remnants of joy and leisure. In one corner, a long-abandoned arcade was filled with dust-covered machines. A broken pinball machine lay tilted against the wall, and the colorful screens of once-popular games blinked on with a flicker of life. 

"Look at this," Jim said, brushing off the dust on a skee-ball machine. "All it needs is a little TLC."

"Or maybe just a miracle," Frida said, shooting a glance at Reid, who was now inspecting the area like it was a treasure map.

They wandered out into the streets, where the sun shone brightly, illuminating the desolation. Shops with faded signs beckoned with long-lost promises of adventure, yet they stood empty, their windows cracked and their doors ajar, like mouths gasping for breath.

"This is the beach, right?" Reid asked, squinting as he looked toward the horizon. "Even the beach is deserted!"

A nearby beach bar caught their attention, its once-vibrant paint now peeling and the palm trees swaying sadly in the breeze. A few sun-bleached lounge chairs sat unattended, a stark contrast to the lively atmosphere they had envisioned.

"We can fix this," Reid declared as they approached the bar. "It just needs a little love."

They began collecting debris and trash, motivated by the idea that this could be the start of their mission. Polly and Olivia found old bottles that could be repurposed, Frida gathered crab traps that appeared salvageable, and Jim discovered a hidden stash of old beach games. 

As the sun began to set, casting warm hues across the sky, they set up their makeshift gathering area. Reid had devised a plan for a “Beach Revival” event that would attract anyone still lingering in Pacifico City. They could offer free drinks, crab-catching contests, and games for the children. Jim even suggested a talent show for those who wanted to entertain.

That night, as they gathered around the fire they had built on the beach, they shared stories of the world before the war and laughed at the absurdity of their situation. For the first time in ages, the weight of the world seemed to lift, if only for a moment. They were alive, together, and ready to take on whatever came next.

Under the darkening skies, Reid stood up, his face lit by the glow of the fire. "Tomorrow, we start cleaning up this beach. But we also need to spread the word. We need to go into town, tell everyone about our plans, and invite them to join us. We can make Pacifico City the place to be again!"

Polly, feeling the spark of hope ignited by Reid’s enthusiasm, nodded. "Let’s do it. We might just win back the city's spirit."

As they all cheered, Olivia felt a twinge of unease flicker in her heart. Would they really be able to pull this off? Would their efforts be enough to bring back the joy that once filled these shores? 

The next day, fueled by determination and a touch of desperation, they set about their tasks. They cleaned the beach, repaired the bar, and hung up faded banners advertising their event. Word began to spread, and slowly but surely, people from neighboring settlements started to trickle in, curious about this unexpected revival.

As the day of the Beach Revival approached, they found themselves swept into a whirlwind of activity. More people arrived, each with their own stories of survival and resilience. The spirit of the beach was beginning to awaken again, a fragile but radiant light in the midst of chaos.

On the day of the event, families gathered, laughter echoed along the shoreline, and for the first time in ages, the sound of music filled the air. They hosted crab races, games, and contests, and Reid even set up a makeshift stage for the talent show. Each performance brought cheers and applause.

Polly watched as her family's dream took shape, and as she caught a glimpse of Reid’s smile, she realized that perhaps they were not the fools she thought they were, but rather the change this city needed. The day ended with a spectacular sunset, painting the sky with colors they had almost forgotten existed.

As the night wound down, the group gathered around a flickering bonfire, the glow casting shadows on their joyful faces. Reid stood to make one last toast, his heart full as he lifted his drink high.

“To Pacifico City! To new beginnings and old friends! And to never giving up on what matters!”

Everyone raised their drinks and cheered, but in the back of Polly’s mind, a lingering thought remained. They had rebuilt a piece of the past, but at what cost? Would their efforts be enough to hold back the chaos that still lingered in the world outside?

With the night sky blanketing them in its embrace, she shook off the uncertainty. For now, they had a moment of peace, and sometimes, that was all that truly mattered.

[Story]: Deep within the bowels of the University of Greyvein, in a far-removed corner of the library, sat two novice scholars with their noses deep in dusty tomes. Ferin, a frigid young man in his early twentieth year, sat hunched over, scanning the pages of an old book detailing predators in Naiadara. Beside him, Rodrick scribbled furiously on a wrinkled yellow notebook, copying the words from another book without bothering to understand them. His beaky nose and strange haircut made him stand out among the other scholars, but not in a good way. Ferin only tolerated his presence because he was the only other Water Wielder among the novice scholars.


Ferin glanced at Rodrick with a scowl, crossing his arms and leaning away from him, barely hiding his frustration. He slammed another book shut, adding it to the pile of useless texts on the table. He crumpled the parchment in his hand, feeling the ink smudge on his fingers. He had spent hours poring over the books, but none of them had the answers he sought.

*Nothing I can use at least,* Ferin thought. *I need something that will impress them.* He wasn't sure who he was referring to.

A sudden movement in his peripheral vision causes Ferin to look to his right and see a man in swishy dark robes walk past the mouth of the aisle with speed. Turning back to his book, he rereads a line about the hunting habits of apex predators.

"Good afternoon gentlemen. You're the two novice Water Invokers, right"

Both men were surprised by the gravelly voice, turning slowly to face the source, who stood leaning on Ferin's chair with one arm. "Yes…" Rodrick answers timidly. "And you are?" Ferin kicked his foot under the desk, gesturing with a sharp eye motion to the gold insignia etched into his loose black sleeves.

*I can't say I've ever seen a High Scholar wear those colours before*, Ferin thought. The man looked young at first glance, but the deep facial creases and streaks of grey betrayed his true age.

Rodrick dropped his head. "My apologies Venerable Scholar. What do you need of us?"

"I am High Scholar Amren. Eminence Barik, your superior, informs me you are Invokers? If so, I have a little invitation I think you'll be interested in. Are either of you familiar with the Arbiter?"

"As in the Traverser?" Ferin asked. Nervously, he fidgeted with the small sky-blue gem dangling on a chain earring. "I read about it, but I didn't think it was real."

"You'd be partially justified for believing that based on what some of those dusty tomes might say. It has been dormant for a long time, but it has recently been detected in the jungle of Northern Ashijan. If you can tolerate the three days it'll take to walk there, there will be great reward in locating it." The man spoke a bit above a whisper. "Wealth and influence as scholars for sure, and if you manage to make a deal with it, you would have access to the most powerful Traverser in all Naiadara."

"Why us?" Ferin asked, narrowing his eyes. "Wouldn't the other High Scholars want to keep this under wraps?" He didn't trust the High Scholar's smile. There had to be a catch.

This time it was Rodrick"s turn to kick. "Don't be rude, Ferin. The business of the High Scholars is their own." He grinned at the High Scholar, not caring about the consequences. "What he means to say is that we are interested and that he knows not to look a gift horse in the mouth. Right, Ferin?"

Ferin's eyes flickered to the window, where he imagined his parents finally welcoming him home. He swallowed hard and nodded. Facing the man again, he forced out a reply, his voice cracking slightly. "Yes, we are interested. How hard do you think it will be?"

*It seems almost too good to be true*, he thought. *But even on the off chance it is… I could get them out of that hovel, and secure a good life for them.*

It was vain, and he knew it, but his interest had been piqued and found he had already made his decision. Turning back to the man, he said, with a hint of doubt in his voice, "Yes, we are interested. How hard do you think it will be?"

High Scholar Amren withdrew a small folded page of parchment containing a detailed image of a small section of the jungle where the Arbiter can be found. With a hopeful smile and a scratchy voice, he said, "I don't think there will be much struggle."

Without another word, he walked back up the aisle and around the corner. Ferin looked at Rodrick, both of them quickly processing what just occurred before promptly gathering their belongings from the desk and hurrying up the aisle and out of the library toward the dormitory. After pausing at Ferin's door, they decide to pack their belongings today for an early departure, and Rodrick hurries off to his room.

A few moments after Ferin began to pack, his door bangs open to admit Rodrick, who closes the door and pauses to catch his breath before asking an inane question about shoes. Ferin began to ask him to leave when the door banged open for a second time, this time to reveal their instructor, Eminence Barik. A plump man with entirely too much weight on his hips and a shiny bald head currently the same pink as his exasperated face.

"What is all this running about?" He demanded. "I saw you both burst in here like tubby children in a candy store! What's gotten you so riled up?"

He paused briefly, looking at the paper on the desk and then at Ferin, who was motionless with a bag in one hand, a pair of pants in the other, and a small heap of clothes and other items on his bed. Then he looked at Rodrick, who was holding a different pair of shoes in either hand and back at Ferin.

"Why does it look like you are going somewhere?"

Rodrick spoke before Ferin could. "We were given a task by a High Scholar to seek a Traverser in Ashijan." His face was a few shades paler than usual and he stood at attention, clasping his hands behind his back with enough force to send a shoe flying from his grip.

Barik paid it no mind.

"A High Scholar? Ashijan?" Barik repeated incredulously. His eyes suddenly sharpened like a hawk"s, and he darted to the paper on the desk, barely beating Ferin to it. He scanned it for a moment before Ferin yanked it out of his grasp, but it was too late. "The Arbiter? But that's…no…hold on. Wait right here. You do not have permission to leave until I have it in writing or else I will have you expelled!"

He dashed out of the room and down the hall, likely to the High Scholar's audience chamber. Ferin's heart thundered in his ears as he assessed his options as quickly as possible.

After coming to an uneasy decision, he said, "Rodrick, if you're coming, pack everything you need in the next five minutes and meet me by the southernmost gate. We leave now, not tomorrow."

"But-" He began.

"Do as you will. I will wait two minutes and then I will leave. With or without you." Ferin said sharply, not even looking at the other man as he continued shoving bits of clothing into his bag.

Rodrick said nothing else as he sprinted out of the room. Ferin forced himself to be as meticulous as possible while packing to distract himself from the tingling anxiety building in his chest. Not that he's nervous about going, but because he is unsure if he just made a mistake allowing Rodrick to come alongside him.

*If it comes down to him or me, he won't get in my way.*

Ferin was finished with his bag, and just before leaving, he paused, pulling open the bottom drawer of his desk and withdrawing a small rectangular wooden box from underneath a stack of books. Within, submerged in water from this morning"s high tide, was an earring with a grape-size arctic blue gem attached to a short silver chain. The gem on both earrings is known as an Ego and is crucial for all elemental magical Wielding, including Ferin's Invoking.

Ferin felt far more confident sensing the larger gem swing, knowing it was money well spent despite spending literally everything he owned to buy it. Ferin"s gaze flickered to the faded portrait of his family on his desk; the only copy they had between them. The potential of providing for them and proving his worth as an Invoker and Scholar fuelled a newfound determination. The sudden well of power tugging at his ear was momentarily disconcerting but he pushed it out of his mind before rushing out of the room.

After a speedy walk, he arrives at the southern exit from the University grounds. It was a tall wrought iron gate, part of a taller perimeter wall, that Ferin chose due to its immediate proximity to a small pond.

Behind trees, he quickly dropped his belongings, using a smooth stone to hastily write a note to his family telling them he would be away for a few days but that he felt this was finally his moment. Tying the note with twine, he creeps to the nearby water.

As he submerged his right hand, Eo, the pent-up magical energy within the Ego, rushed into him. The gem at his ear glowed brightly from within. A surge of power coursed through his body like a riptide, radiating off his skin and warping like hot air above a campfire. The pond responded, its surface rippling with an iridescent sheen.

Closing his eyes, he senses Naiadara, the wellspring dimension fuelling all Water Wielding and housing the creatures Invokers summon. Seconds later, he feels a pushback on his magic, indicating his bait has been taken. The pond ceased to be just water; it became a gateway to a hidden world. It was no longer a mere surface but a doorway to Naiadara, the manifestation of his Invoking ability to pierce through the veil between realms.

He opened his eyes just in time to see a blurred shape shooting upward and landing behind Ferin with a wet thump.

Turning, he examined the Traverser—a bulky amphibian creature, perched on strong hopping legs, with a flat shell, snapping beak, and toadlike dark blue-grey skin. The Croakshell stared blankly at him, awaiting a command, but Ferin ignored it for now.

Getting up, Ferin harnessed the pond"s lingering Eo, dismissing the portal and raising a water sphere above his head with a sweep of his hand. His focus intensified, and he immersed his senses into Naiadara once more. Delicately, he sought his target, detecting its erratic movements responding to the subtle allure of his Eo bait. The ball began to shrink into itself, its centre darkening before ballooning outward. With a satisfying pop, the bubble burst, revealing a small Traverser hovering above the trees.

"A Flitterfly!"

Ferin nearly yelped, turning to see Rodrick looking excitedly upward at the creature, a slightly bulbous bag slung on his back and kept in place with a brown strap across his chest.

"Keep it down or I will leave you behind," Ferin hissed. "I need it to deliver a note and we can leave. I want to get as much of a head start as possible before night falls."

He turned his attention back to the Flitterfly, giving it a mental command to land on his arm. With its speed and sense of direction, this Traverser was the Naiadara equivalent of a carrier pigeon, making it useful for delivering messages. It had shimmering sky-blue scales and pointed dorsal and caudal fin alongside two insectoid eyes with two sets of wide membranous wings that flapped faster than the eye could see.

It grabbed the rolled note with its two front legs before kicking off with its remaining four, whizzing through the sky toward his parents" farm an hour north of the Greyvein city walls. Ferin hoped his parents would read his note, but he had a nagging feeling that he should've gone to see them himself.

*I don't want to think about that right now. Just focus on the trip.*

Quickly closing the distance, Rodrick stuck his face uncomfortably close. "Is that a new Ego? I thought the gem was smaller before."

"It was." Ferin said, pulling it out of his ear while taking a cautious step back. "This is a Grade Two that I paid through the nose to get." He traced his fingers over the gem, seeing its once-bright hue had darkened into a deep azure, perfectly mirroring the shade of Ferin's eyes.

"I wish I had one that nice. I'm stuck with the basic one the University loaned me." Rodrick moaned ignorantly.

"Work as hard as I do and you'll get there one day."

"You know everyone calls both of us 'The Piddles', right?"

"Shut up, Piddles. Let's get moving."

The pair walked out of the University grounds and into the bustle of the city with the Traverser hopping alongside them. They had to push their way through, but the crowds helped immensely to conceal them and their batrachian companion, who had no issue weaving through the people to stay as close as possible. Ferin kept the parchment from the High Scholar on his person at all times because, without it, they would have no chance of locating The Arbiter or the riches at the end.

The gaggle of guards posted at the city gate gave them a quizzical look, first for their novice scholar robes, and then for the remarkably strange animal accompanying them, but allowed them both to pass without any hassle.

*Probably because we're leaving instead of entering*, Ferin thought humorously. But he still did not dare lower his guard yet. Just because they had escaped the confines of the city hardly guaranteed their safe passage. *The University is certainly preparing to send a force after us, for if the information I carry is true…*

Ferin shuddered, suddenly feeling the implications of his actions. He clenched his teeth and hoped, with every fiber of his being, that he was not embarking on a fool's errand. However, Ferin was so absorbed in these thoughts that he failed to notice the mental link to his Flitterfly forcibly severed before reaching the city limits."

Ferin and Rodrick trudged through the cobbled streets of Greyvein, the weight of their decision pressing heavily on their shoulders. The sun hung low in the sky, casting elongated shadows that danced ominously along the walls of nearby buildings. Ferin glanced back, half expecting to see the familiar silhouette of Eminence Barik, but the bustling crowd swallowed their escape whole, shielding them from prying eyes—at least for now.

“Do you think we’ll really find it?” Rodrick asked, breaking the silence. He had fallen slightly behind, his eyes darting nervously at every passerby.

“If it’s there, we’ll find it,” Ferin replied, trying to project confidence. “High Scholar Amren wouldn’t have sent us if he didn’t think it was possible.”

Rodrick nodded, albeit skeptically, as they made their way toward the Northern Ashijan trail. The path was a narrow dirt route winding between the outskirts of the city and the looming forests beyond. Ferin felt a mix of excitement and trepidation—this was a chance for greatness, an opportunity to prove himself. But the thought of the Arbiter, the myth that had kept scholars awake at night, loomed larger than he had expected.

As they neared the edge of Greyvein, Ferin felt the familiar pulse of Eo within him. It was a comforting presence, yet he couldn’t shake the feeling he was being watched. He pulled out the parchment with the map, studying it intently. The lines and symbols were almost indecipherable to his untrained eye, but he squinted at the markings, tracing the route they needed to take.

“Stop fidgeting, Piddles!” Ferin snapped, annoyed by the unrelenting energy radiating off Rodrick. “We need to focus.”

Rodrick huffed in response. “I’m just trying to stay alert! We’re out here in the wilderness. Anything could happen, especially with a High Scholar’s business on our backs.”

The mention of the High Scholar sent a shiver down Ferin’s spine. It was one thing to dream of adventure; it was another to be pursued for it. He hoped the veil of night would cloak their tracks, giving them a chance to reach Arbiter before anyone from the University caught wind of their intentions.

As they pressed on, the trees began to thicken around them, their towering canopies casting flickering shadows on the ground. The air was cooler here, filled with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. Ferin pulled the straps of his bag tighter on his shoulders, feeling the weight of their task ahead. 

“Do you think we should have gotten supplies?” Rodrick said, his voice low as they ventured deeper into the foliage.

“No.” Ferin replied, annoyance creeping back into his tone. “We have what we need. If we’re lucky, we’ll find something useful along the way.”

A rustle in the underbrush made them both freeze. Ferin's heart raced as he scanned the surroundings. “What was that?” he whispered, his eyes wide.

“Probably just a small animal,” Rodrick said, but his quaking voice betrayed him. 

“Stay close,” Ferin ordered, adjusting the grip on his bag and moving cautiously forward. The feeling of being watched intensified, and he felt the instinct to summon a Traverser rise within him. But he held back, unwilling to draw unnecessary attention. 

Suddenly, the underbrush parted, and a wiry figure emerged—a young woman with dark hair and vibrant green eyes. Dressed in tattered, earth-toned garments, she bore an air of someone accustomed to the wild.

“Lost, are we?” she said, a smirk playing on her lips as she sized them up. 

Ferin’s mind raced. “No, we’re not lost,” he replied, feigning confidence. “We’re on our way to Northern Ashijan. We have important business to attend to.”

The woman chuckled lightly. “Important business? In a place like this?” She tilted her head, eyeing Ferin and Rodrick with suspicion before stepping closer. “I’m Mira. You might want to rethink that path unless you enjoy trouble.”

“What do you mean?” Rodrick asked, taking a step back, wary of her approach.

“There are things in this jungle that aren’t friendly to outsiders,” she warned, her tone serious. “You two don’t seem like seasoned travelers.”

“We can handle ourselves,” Ferin insisted, but doubt wormed its way into his thoughts. He exchanged a glance with Rodrick, who looked as uncertain as he felt.

Mira raised an eyebrow. “Alright then, but if you’re headed to the Arbiter, you’ll need more than just bravado. I can help you navigate the forest and avoid trouble. You’ll be grateful for a guide.”

Ferin hesitated. “What’s in it for you?”

A glimmer of mischief danced in her eyes. “Let’s just say I have my reasons. Plus, it’s more fun to have company when facing danger.” She stepped back, crossing her arms, waiting for their answer.

Rodrick looked hopeful. “What do you think, Ferin? We could use the help.”

Ferin considered it carefully. While he was reluctant to trust a stranger, the prospect of having someone familiar with the terrain outweighed his reservations. “Fine. But if you’re leading us into a trap, I won’t hesitate to unleash my Traversers on you.” 

Mira laughed lightly, the tension easing. “Don’t worry, I’m not your enemy. Come, let’s get moving before the nightfall raises the stakes.”

With Mira leading the way, Ferin and Rodrick exchanged relieved glances, buoyed by the idea of safety in numbers. They trekked deeper into the jungle, the vibrant sounds of the wild surrounding them—chirps and rustles carried through the air like an orchestra.

As they walked, Mira shared bits of lore about the jungle, its history, and the creatures that roamed within it. “There are whispers about the Arbiter,” she said casually, “but not all of them paint a pretty picture. Some say it grants wishes; others say it devours those who seek it.”

“Devours?” Rodrick echoed, his eyes growing wide. “What do you mean by that?”

“Let’s just say that not everyone comes back from an encounter with the Arbiter. It has a mind of its own, and it’s not known for being forgiving,” she warned, glancing back at them. 

Ferin's stomach twisted. All the dreams of glory and wealth suddenly felt heavier with the risk. He glanced at Rodrick, who was biting his lip nervously. “But we have to try, right? If we can communicate with it…” 

“Communication is one thing,” Mira interrupted. “What you ask of it is another. If you believe you can persuade it, you better have something of value to offer. Otherwise, you might find yourself in a predicament you can’t escape.”

Rodrick looked at Ferin, who wondered if they’d truly prepared for the consequences of their ambition. The jungle’s dense foliage swallowed the last rays of sunlight, and the atmosphere thickened, revealing an eerie stillness.

“Are we close?” Ferin asked, trying to keep the tremor from his voice.

“Almost,” Mira replied, her tone suddenly serious. “But we need to be careful. There are creatures here that won’t take kindly to intruders.”

As they pressed on, shadows danced between the trees, and the air thickened with tension. Ferin felt the prickle of apprehension crawling up his spine. He was about to step into the realm of legends and unknowns, where his dreams of proving himself could easily turn into nightmares.

A sudden crack echoed from the underbrush. Ferin whipped around, his heart racing. “What was that?”

Mira raised her hand, signaling for silence. “Stay close.” 

The three of them froze, and Ferin’s heart pounded in his chest. His body thrummed with energy, the Eo swirling within him. He prepared to summon a Traverser, ready to defend themselves, but the moment stretched into an eternity. Just as he was about to call forth power, a massive creature burst forward from the foliage—a sleek, shadowy form with rippling muscles and gleaming eyes.

It was an apex predator.

Ferin barely had time to think when Mira shouted, “Run! We need to get away!”

Without a second thought, he turned and sprinted deeper into the jungle, adrenaline flooding his veins. Rodrick followed closely behind, his breaths coming in frantic gasps. They dove through the underbrush, branches whipping against their bodies as the creature pursued them, its growls echoing ominously in the air.

“Ferin! Do something!” Rodrick shouted, his panic palpable.

Ferin felt the energy within him surge, but he was afraid—afraid to unleash his powers in the chaos of their escape. He glanced back, catching a glimpse of the predator gaining ground. The moonlight filtered through the trees, illuminating the beast’s sharp teeth and predatory gaze.

“Summon the Croakshell!” Mira urged, her voice cutting through the noise. “It can help us!”

Ferin’s heart sank, but he knew she was right. He had to act. With a sweep of his arms, he called forth the Croakshell from its waiting place. The amphibian creature emerged with a splattering thump, ready to assist. 

“Distract it!” Ferin commanded, and the Croakshell sprang into action, lunging toward the predator with a ferocious croak.

The creature paused, momentarily distracted by the Croakshell as it charged. Ferin seized the opportunity, feeling the surge of Eo within him. He focused, twisting the energy into a sphere of water that flickered with dazzling light. 

“Now!” he shouted, launching the sphere toward the predator. It burst open in a dazzling explosion, dousing the beast in a torrent of water. The creature stumbled, growling in surprise, and for a moment, they had the upper hand.

“Run, now!” Mira shouted again, and they darted past the disoriented predator. The jungle opened up before them, and they raced toward a clearing, their hearts pounding in unison.

As they broke through the treeline, the vastness of the Northern Ashijan jungle lay before them. The moon hung overhead, illuminating the path ahead, and Ferin felt a sense of hope surge within him. They were closer to the Arbiter, but the threats they faced were far more tangible than they had anticipated.

Behind them, the predator roared in frustration, and as they turned to look back, Ferin knew they had only begun to face the challenges of their journey. The Arbiter awaited them, but it was not the only force in these woods.

“Let’s get moving,” Ferin urged, determination replacing fear in his chest. “We’re going to find the Arbiter, and nothing will stop us.”

With Mira leading the way, they pressed onward into the darkness of the jungle, prepared to face whatever trials lay ahead. The stakes were higher than ever, and their journey had only just begun.

[Story]: Zita hears this and slowly hovers a hand over his mouth, eyes focused and eyebrows arched as he ruminates, processing the choice laid out before him, and he has no chance to delay. He has to make this. Pause occurs as the two stay silent a second.


*... Go home, or learn how to exorcize ghosts? This... this is a lot... I...* Zita nervously thinks, trying to figure out what is right.

Sylvie sorely sighs in response to this.

"... I"ll give you time. Check back with you in fifteen minutes. Think long and hard. Sorry."

And with that announcement, Sylvie vanishes behind the bars and leaves Zita on his own. He thinks long and hard about this decision.

*... I... I want to leave. I want to go home, I want to hang out with Pip, go to school, go to bed, I want to pretend none of this ever happened! I want to live an ordinary life and study, I don"t want to be involved in any of this, it"s all... but... I... I will be seeing these ghosts everywhere, whether I stay or not. I"ll have to witness them, but not know a thing about them or why they"re here. Or what can be done if they try to hurt people, like how that one tried to kill me... and, I won"t get to see this world behind the scenes, with all these factions and secrets inside...It"ll go on without me, forever outside of my view. I want to see it, I have to, but... urgh… how did I end up in this mess?*

Zita ponders the dilemma more, staring at the floor with locked hands as he argues with himself, wondering how he got into this mess and if he's still dreaming. He can't decide if the fifteen minutes felt like 15 seconds or 15 hours, but they end either way and the strange woman is back. She stands before him with crossed arms for a second before asking the big question.

"... so? You made your choice?" a pause washes over the two, but Zita's lip parts and the answer emerges.

"... yeah... I... I think I have." Zita responds, anxiety and caution in his tone. He gulps before sealing his fate, giving the verdict on his life;

"I... I want to learn about ghosts. and what to do about them."

With that response, Sylvie gives a confident smile as the cell bars retract and upward, rising and letting Zita out of the cage.

"... Atta boy. Let"s get started." a proud smirk across her face as Zita steps out into the light, a nervous smile across his face as he follows the woman outside the cage.

"Now, lets begin!" Sylvie enthusiastically declares as they walk out of a white-plastered cottage that you wouldn"t guess to be the front for an underground holding facility. Before the two is a shiny black car.

"... s... so, where do we... start?" Zita asks Sylvie in a shy tone.

"Well~ first, it would be smart for you to get some first hand experience. You"ll be assisting us on an exorcism! We"ll tell you more when we get there." The black car"s back door opens to reveal a woman in the same robe he saw the previous person wear, but with their hood down. She has lengthy raven black hair in a braided ponytail and small facial features. Her eyes widen from shock as she sees the boy in front of the car.

"Oh- he actually took the option?" The driver states in a surprised tone before clearing her voice. The black haired girl stares at him with a shocked look. Zita replies with an awkward lopsided smile.

"As I said, I teach this one. You"ll be her classmate, if that"s alright. And if it ain"t, sorry, not much to do about it." Sylvie says as she walks to the shotgun side of the car. Zita slowly takes a seat and gives a small wave to the girl.

"... what… are you doing here?" She scowls at the boy next to her.

"... I... I want to learn about the ghosts..."

"I..." the girl stares at Sylvie with an annoyed look and crosses her arms in a sulk. The driver in the front, a woman with a blonde bob cut turns the keys as the car rattles, starting and beginning to move not long after.

*... the awkwardness hurts, I... yikes. How am I already regretting this, before I've even met a ghost nonetheless?*

The road trip that follows amplifies the awkwardness to levels that the 2 didn"t even know was possible. The driver remains quiet for most of the journey, whilst Sylvie hums to the radio. Meanwhile, the two in the back don"t even say a word, the girl in the back staring out the window at the world passing by whilst Zita thinks of anything to say. Finally, Sylvie speaks.

"Oh- right. Zita, this is Assira Kaguya. Assira, Zita! Both of you will be learning from me during this crash course, so get along nicely!" Sylvie informs.

"Y- yes, miss!" Zira nods as he responds, talking anxiously.

"... yes, miss..." Assira responds, sounding like she"s talking through gritted teeth, making Zita even more uncomfortable.

The black car travels quite some distance, the destination leads to the people inside weaving through the Welsh countryside, tracing the roads lining the valleys. The long journey gives Zita a lot of time to think.

*... What... What just happened? Why did it happen? How did it happen? Did... did I fall down the stairs in the bunker and this is all one big concussion dream? Would make more sense than being suffocated by thin air and the creepy statue taking a rock to my head... not to mention what the hell this creepy woman was talking about, aether and plasm and... look, I"ll just... go with it. I have to know. I"ll regret it if I don"t.*

"So, Zita!" Sylvie announces to the boy. "We will be going on a mission, learning first hand. We"ll help, of course."

"W- why so soon?" Zita asks.

"Aether comes from aetherplasm, which spawns from negative emotions. Mainly the fight or flight response. The best way to unlock aether control is through life or death stress!" Sylvie talks about life or death as naturally as she breathes, prompting Zita to develop an expression of shock and fear.

"B- but I don"t want to die!-"

"You won"t~ you"ll live! We"ll be here to protect you!"

"... o... okay..." sweat rolls down Zita"s face as he finds that cold comfort. After this exchange, the driver speaks.

"Miss, if you may debrief..." the driver asks Sylvie.

"Rrrright people! Here"s the summary of what"s happened and whatcha gonna do. whatcha need to know; This mineshaft is known to be haunted." The lady says, as if what she is saying is completely standard to the two in the back. Assira simply nods with a blank face, robe hood down. Meanwhile, Zira is still taking time to adjust.

"Now then, this mineshaft..." Sylvie continues whilst twiddling with the branch in her hair, twisting it in her locks. "It all started in the 1900"s, dead early in it too. A mines owner did not pay enough on safety precautions because "mah monah."" She breaks up the serious topic with a goofy voice when talking about the money. "Due to this oversight, an coaldust incident and poor scaffolding caused portions of shaft to collapse, burying the miners still inside." Sylvie explains this tragedy in a casual and nonchalant way, resting her arm against the top of her seat whilst talking to the two students. "Ok then, Assira!" The teacher says to the girl, raising their index finger as she talks. "Pop quiz! Our new friend here just learned about ghosts and aether existing, so I"ll test your knowledge and give our new guy here a crash course. Got it?"

"Understood, miss." The robed girl responds in a stoic and formal tone, if annoyed by their teacher"s silly tone. Zita just sits there, a bit concerned as he twitchily nods and prepares to listen.

"Now! How are ghosts formed?" The teacher asks.

"Simple. Negative emotions radiate from living people in the form of an energy known as aetherplasm. Said energy then imprinting itself on surrounding objects and ground. human souls transfer into aetherplasm during traumatic deaths. Eventually the aetherplasm in the ground attracts each other, assumes the identity of the negative emotion and collective thoughts that created it, and begins to operate as a ghost. It will also attract negative emotions linked to the identity it assumed."

"Ding ding ding! Full marks! You got all that...? sorry, didn"t get your last name." The teacher turns to Zita, her jovial attitude turning to a more curious one when asking the boy.

The boy turns to her nervously and stutters; "U-uh, it"s malik, miss... Zita Malik. and, yeah, I think I understand... so manifestations of bad memories and fears, in short?"

The teacher looks to the ceiling whilst thinking about that name, as if remembering something. "Zita, huh... I like it! Anyway, yeah, that"s a good way to put it!" The teacher responds, then clicks her fingers.

"Anyway, people like us- those who have been touched by aether by birth or events- can manipulate our aetherplasm to create aether, a more controllable form, the soul made plasma. Plus, access to aether allows us to perceive ghosts, something normal people can"t. Also, We can manipulate our aether in many ways, everyone has their own individual method and technique. I"m sure you"ll see it from Assira. On your mission" The teacher explains, then turns to the girl in question. "Speaking of, Assira. I trust you to look after our new recruit. You got him into this mess, so I trust you to look out for him whilst here." The teacher states in a more serious tone, yet still informal. Assira's eyes widen in frustration and she goes to speak back, but doesn"t open her mouth.

"Yes, miss..." she responds, tone radiating frustration. Zita watches, quietly, not wanting to say anything on the matter...

Zita"s head is on fire and his stomach is in knots as he waits for the journey to end. He didn"t know what the hell he"s done to deserve being in this situation other than to be curious, but...

*I made this bed, guess it"s time to lie in it!* he figured begrudgingly.

After an hour, the car pulls through an rickety metal fence, driving through a blackened and coal dust covered road and parks in the middle of an abandoned early 1900"s coal mine. Derelict minecarts and eroded railways line the floor, scaffold towers flake rust and stand with wheels atop and dusty chimneys litter the skyline, the glum scenery emphasized by the signature welsh clouds hanging overhead. The students walk out the back of the car, Assira hastily slamming the door behind them and into Zita whom blocks it with an alarmed expression. The teacher walks out and leans against the car"s driver side door and crosses their arms, the driver opening the window.

"We"ll be out here standing guard. If something comes up, I"ll be there in a split. I trust you though, you two got this. best of luck!" The teacher says to her pupils, smiling and with a cheery tone.

"Good luck, you two." The driver says, slightly more detached yet hopefully as the two begin to approach the pits."
